valueFormat.structure: Array<{ id: string | number; name: string; route?: string; disabled?: boolean; badge?: number; icon?: string; percentage?: number; }>
valueFormat.notes: Required array defining all tabs. Each tab object must have id and name. Optional fields: route (for routing), disabled, badge (notification count), icon, percentage (for progress tabs). The order in array determines tab display order.

commonMistakes.mistake: Missing id or name in tab objects
commonMistakes.why: Component relies on id for tracking and name for display
commonMistakes.impact: Tabs won't render or will show empty labels
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure every tab object has both id and name properties

valueFormat.notes: When true (default), clicking tabs triggers Vue Router navigation using the 'route' property from tabsList. When false, tabs act as simple UI toggles without routing.
valueFormat.example:
true // Enable routing
false // Disable routing for non-navigation tabs

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting useRouter=true without route in tabsList
commonMistakes.why: Routing requires route property on tab objects
commonMistakes.fix: Either add route to tabs or set useRouter=false

valueFormat.notes: When true, tabs that don't fit horizontally are moved into an overflow dropdown menu (three-dot menu). Useful for responsive designs with many tabs.
valueFormat.example: true // Enable overflow dropdown for tabs

valueFormat.notes: Enables drag-and-drop reordering of tabs. When user drops a tab, emits 'changeOrder' event with new tab order. Useful for customizable dashboards.
valueFormat.example: true // Allow users to reorder tabs

valueFormat.notes: Shows a '+' button to add new tabs. Works with addNewTabFunctionality to determine add behavior (dropdown options or custom modal).

valueFormat.structure: Array<{ label: string; value: string | number; icon?: string; }>
valueFormat.notes: Options shown in dropdown when user clicks '+ Add Tab' button (requires addNewTabActive=true and addNewTabFunctionality='options'). Each option represents a tab type user can add.
Determines behavior of '+ Add Tab' button. 'options': shows dropdown with addTabDropdownOptions. 'custom': emits addNewTab event for custom handling (e.g., open modal).
valueFormat.example:
'options' // Show dropdown
'custom' // Emit event for custom modal

valueFormat.notes: Shows 'Rename' option in tab context menu (right-click or dropdown). When clicked, emits 'rename' event with tab data.
Shows 'Remove' option in tab context menu. Default is true. When clicked, emits 'removeTab' or 'delete' event depending on useEmitForRemove.
Shows 'Duplicate' option in tab context menu. When clicked, emits 'duplicate' event with tab data to clone.
Applies box/card styling to tabs instead of default underline style. Creates visually distinct rectangular tabs.
Maximum character length for tab labels before truncation. Set to 0 (default) for no truncation. Truncated text shows full label on hover.
valueFormat.example: 20 // Truncate tab names longer than 20 chars

click.description: Emitted when a tab is clicked
click.payload: { id: string | number; name: string; route?: string; }
click.when: User clicks on a tab. Fired before route navigation if useRouter=true.

changeOrder.description: Emitted when user reorders tabs via drag-and-drop
changeOrder.when: User drops a tab in new position (requires draggable=true). Use to persist new tab order.

addNewTab.description: Emitted when user clicks '+ Add Tab' button with custom functionality
addNewTab.when: User clicks add button and addNewTabFunctionality='custom'. Use to show custom modal/form.

removeTab.description: Emitted when user removes a tab
removeTab.payload: { id: string | number; name: string; index: number; }
removeTab.when: User clicks remove option in tab menu (requires removeOption=true).

rename.description: Emitted when user clicks rename option
rename.when: User clicks rename in tab menu (requires renameOption=true). Use to show rename dialog.

duplicate.description: Emitted when user duplicates a tab
duplicate.when: User clicks duplicate option (requires duplicateOption=true). Use to clone tab with new ID.

basicTabs.title: Basic Tab Navigation
basicTabs.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :useRouter="true"
    @click="handleTabClick"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const tabs = ref([
  { id: 'overview', name: 'Overview', route: '/overview' },
  { id: 'analytics', name: 'Analytics', route: '/analytics', badge: 3 },
  { id: 'settings', name: 'Settings', route: '/settings' }
]);

const handleTabClick = (tab) => {
  console.log('Tab clicked:', tab.name);

draggableTabs.title: Draggable Tabs with Persistence
draggableTabs.description: Allow users to reorder tabs and save order
draggableTabs.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :draggable="true"
    :useRouter="false"
    @changeOrder="saveTabOrder"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const tabs = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Dashboard' },
  { id: 2, name: 'Reports' },
  { id: 3, name: 'Users' }
]);

const saveTabOrder = ({ newOrder }) => {
  tabs.value = newOrder;
  localStorage.setItem('tabOrder', JSON.stringify(newOrder));
};

// Load saved order on mount
onMounted(() => {
  const saved = localStorage.getItem('tabOrder');
  if (saved) tabs.value = JSON.parse(saved);
});
</script>

dynamicTabs.title: Dynamic Tabs with Add/Remove
dynamicTabs.description: Allow users to add and remove tabs
dynamicTabs.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :addNewTabActive="true"
    :addNewTabFunctionality="'options'"
    :addTabDropdownOptions="addOptions"
    :removeOption="true"
    @addNewTab="handleAddTab"
    @removeTab="handleRemoveTab"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const tabs = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Home' }
]);

const addOptions = [
  { label: 'Add Chart', value: 'chart' },
  { label: 'Add Table', value: 'table' }
];

let nextId = 2;
const handleAddTab = (option) => {
  tabs.value.push({
    id: nextId++,
    name: option.label,
    type: option.value
  });
};

const handleRemoveTab = ({ id }) => {
  tabs.value = tabs.value.filter(tab => tab.id !== id);
};
</script>

styling.notes: Box-style tabs (boxStyle=true) have distinct rectangular appearance with borders. Default style uses underline for active tab.

implementationPatterns.name: Responsive Tab Overflow
implementationPatterns.description: Handle many tabs gracefully on small screens using dropdown overflow
implementationPatterns.when: You have 5+ tabs or tab names are long. Prevents horizontal scrolling and layout breaking.
pros: Clean UI even with many tabs
cons: Tabs in dropdown are less discoverable
Requires extra click for overflow tabs

implementationPatterns.name: Controlled Tab State (Non-Router)
implementationPatterns.description: Manually control active tab without routing, useful for sub-navigation
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :useRouter="false"
    @click="activeTab = $event.id"
  />
  <component :is="tabComponents[activeTab]" />
</template>

<script setup>
const activeTab = ref('overview');
const tabComponents = {
  overview: OverviewTab,
  details: DetailsTab
};
</script>
implementationPatterns.when: Tabs control content within a page/modal, not entire routes. Common in settings panels, wizards, or detail views.

implementationPatterns.name: Persistent Tab Customization
implementationPatterns.description: Save user's tab order, added tabs, and preferences to localStorage/backend
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="userTabs"
    :draggable="true"
    :addNewTabActive="true"
    @changeOrder="saveTabs"
    @addNewTab="saveTabs"
    @removeTab="saveTabs"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const userTabs = ref([]);

// Load on mount
onMounted(async () => {
  const saved = await api.getUserTabs();
  userTabs.value = saved || defaultTabs;
});

const saveTabs = () => {
  api.saveUserTabs(userTabs.value);
};
</script>
implementationPatterns.when: Building customizable dashboards where users can personalize their workflow. Common in analytics platforms, CRM tools.

useCases.title: Multi-Section Dashboard Navigation
useCases.description: Primary navigation between major dashboard sections with route-based tabs
useCases.example: Marketing platform with tabs for Campaigns, Audiences, Analytics, Reports, and Settings. Each tab navigates to different route with its own sub-pages.

useCases.title: Report Builder with Dynamic Tabs
useCases.description: Allow users to add multiple report tabs, each with different data views
useCases.example: Analytics dashboard where users can add chart tabs, table tabs, or metric cards. Tabs are draggable, renameable, and removable for custom layouts.

useCases.title: Multi-Step Form Wizard
useCases.description: Progress indicator showing completion status for each step
useCases.example: Onboarding flow with Account Setup → Profile → Preferences → Complete. Box-style tabs with percentage indicators show progress. Previous steps are clickable, future steps are disabled.

useCases.title: Settings Panel Organization
useCases.description: Organize complex settings into categorized tabs without route changes
useCases.example: Account settings with General, Security, Notifications, Integrations tabs. Uses useRouter=false to keep settings in one route with tab-based content switching.

bestPractices.title: Limit Active Tab Count
bestPractices.description: Keep visible tabs to 5-7 maximum, use dropdownTabs for overflow
bestPractices.reasoning: Too many visible tabs cause cognitive overload and UI crowding. Overflow dropdown keeps interface clean while maintaining access to all tabs.

bestPractices.title: Always Provide Unique IDs
bestPractices.description: Use stable, unique identifiers for tab IDs, not array indices
bestPractices.reasoning: Stable IDs ensure correct tab tracking when reordering, adding, or removing tabs. Array indices break when tabs are rearranged.

bestPractices.title: Disable Navigation During Loading
bestPractices.description: Temporarily disable tabs during async operations to prevent race conditions
bestPractices.reasoning: Prevents users from switching tabs mid-operation, which could cause data inconsistency or incomplete saves.

bestPractices.title: Use Badge Numbers Sparingly
bestPractices.description: Only show badges for actionable notifications, not just counts
bestPractices.reasoning: Badges should indicate items requiring user attention. Overuse reduces their effectiveness and creates visual noise.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using array index as tab ID
commonMistakes.why: Indices change when tabs are reordered or removed
commonMistakes.impact: Active tab tracking breaks, wrong tab gets selected after reorder
commonMistakes.fix: Use stable unique identifiers (string or UUID)

commonMistakes.why: Tab order changes are not persisted
commonMistakes.impact: Users reorder tabs but changes are lost on refresh
commonMistakes.fix: Listen to changeOrder event and save new order
Either add route to all tabs or set useRouter=false

commonMistakes.why: Long labels break layout on small screens
commonMistakes.impact: Horizontal scrolling, overlapping tabs, poor mobile UX

performanceNotes.description: Badge counts that update frequently can cause excessive re-renders
performanceNotes.recommendation: Debounce or throttle badge count updates. Use computed properties with proper dependencies.
performanceNotes.impact: High: Constant badge updates can make tabs feel sluggish

performanceNotes.description: Don't render all tab content simultaneously
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use v-if or dynamic components to render only active tab content. Use keep-alive if switching between tabs should preserve state.
performanceNotes.impact: Medium: Pre-rendering all tabs increases initial load time

performanceNotes.description: Rendering 20+ tabs can slow down tab bar
performanceNotes.recommendation: Enable dropdownTabs to hide overflow tabs. Consider if that many tabs indicates a UX problem (maybe use nested navigation instead).
performanceNotes.impact: Medium: Large tab lists affect render performance

accessibilityNotes.description: Tab component should support arrow key navigation between tabs
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure users can navigate tabs with Left/Right arrows and activate with Enter/Space. Test with keyboard only.

accessibilityNotes.description: Tab action buttons (rename, remove, duplicate) need accessible labels
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure dropdown menu options have proper aria-labels. Screen reader should announce 'Rename Dashboard tab' not just 'Rename'.

accessibilityNotes.description: Users should understand why a tab is disabled
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use tooltips or aria-describedby to explain disabled state. Example: 'Complete Step 1 to unlock Step 2'.

accessibilityNotes.description: Focus should move to tab content after selection
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: When tab changes, focus should move to first interactive element in tab panel for keyboard users.
